bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, July 9, 1899

div1.p: Carter discusses his public health work in Cuba. He comments on the American presence in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, July 9, 1899
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
Office of Medical Officer in Command,
Marine-Hospital Service,
Havana Cuba
July 9, 1899
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
I have straightened the first kind of my-
work - in the design at least. Got rid of an
unsatisfactory Assistant & have a good
one, Menocal, in his place. Arranged
for the baggage work & got a decent crew
on the Protector - had to buy a lighter
with sails - sort of flat schooner with out a
Jib. The baggage work, which has
been such a night mare begins
Wednesday. It will be done. With
much row & trouble at first, but it
will be done & be smooth by Aug 31.
I am really earnestly desireous of a
few more cases of yellow fever here, to keep
the Americans away. Their Since
C1
B29
it is bound to exist to some
extent, their presence in the
numbers that are here, is a
menace to the country &
enormously increases my
work

The Cattle boats-are the next problem & then
the Morganline: both troublesome. There is
much to do & I do not see the end: but at least I have
done a weeks work.

I rec'd your letter enclosing one from Ned. Also
the enclosed. I was surprised.

I am absolutely well: not feeling vigorous or speci-
ally happy - but well, I mind the heat, as much
as in N. O. no more. It is about as hot: not quite
I think, & less wet: but the sun is hotter,
still. “there is small choice of rotten apples”
& I mind heat more than I use to.
Have seen Norman; but have seen no one
else save in passing, in about two more
weeks it may be I can rest more; but just
now I am working - not too much & I am too
C1
B29
taking good care of myself & resting at
night. That you all are doing well & are
half way cool at North River is the
greatest consolation I have. If my work
goes well I am satisfied.

Dear love to mother & to all at North River &
especially to yourself & the children
div1.closer:
Your affec'ate husband H. R. Carter You cannot tell how glad I was that
you had an easy trip. Did you get my letter
written aboard the Olivette
H. R C
I have to exercise a kind of general supervision
over the island as I did before - as I am still
“Inspector of Q.'s'” have had to do by mail &
wire however
